task.title: Synchronize Pairs Configuration
task.shortdesc: This topic details steps for keeping configuration files synchronized between component pairs.

context.p: The csync2 utility can be used to achieve this, it's designed to keep configuration consistent between systems in large clusters. The following example uses two standalone Walrus systems.
context.note: Only perform these steps between HA pairs containing the same components to ensure the configuration matches. For assistance in implementing more advanced tasks the csync2 man pages should be consulted directly.

Completion of this section is optional. You might also want to expand on this example and generate your own more complex configurations for other components, adding more groups and including additional files in the synchronization tasks.

Next, ensure the csync2 service and xinetd are set to start at boot on both Walrus systems:

info.codeblock: chkconfig csync2 on chkconfig xinetd on service xinetd restart

step.cmd: Next, perform a dry-run sync to check for proposed changes. Run this on your primary Walrus.
If you are happy with the proposed changes, go ahead and perform the sync.

With the initial synchronization complete, a periodic compare and sync could be run via a cronjob which runs the csync2 utility every 5 minutes. In the future, changes can be made to the synchronized files on your primary Walrus and these would be propagated to the other system by the cronjob.
